body: I am pretty sure it's a duplicate, yet I can't find the original ticket.
There was a pull request. It's not super trivial. We could add the local device name to the conflict file when creating it though, which could be useful when it's synced to other devices.

@calmh I haven't read any code yet in Syncthing, I'm thinking about a way for all syncthings to know which file is which (as in renaming both files to wherever they came from). But i don't yet know how things work, so i can't say too much.
But indeed, creating the file with the devicename could be v0.1, there can always be further improvements lateron :)

I actually think it''s impossible in some cases, as we don't track where the file originated from, and if you were offline for N hours, come back online, there are 10 other devices which have a conflicting copy which would be considered inferior to the one you have, which device are you conflicting with? All 10 of them?

Also we would never use device name, as these things vary between devices and can be user adjusted, so might make no sense on other machines. Lastly when we create a conflict it becomes just "another file" with a different name, so having different names on different sides makes no sense, as the conflict resolution logic is the same on all devices, therefore the outcome is also the same on all sides, hence the name should be the same.

@AudriusButkevicius When a device detects a conflict, it creates another file. Which will be synced with everyone, then including some kind of name would help others know who it originated from.

Imaginary example:
User 1 has his computer offline, writes things to document & save, then comes online (without instantly noticing the conflict).
User 2 has his computer online, writes things to document & save.
User 3 has his computer online, sees that there's a conflict, sees that the conflict is with User1, which is a respectable member of this folder family, and therefore he manually merges them, then remove the conflict files.

I think it could be valuable, but might not fit syncthings goals :)

It's hard to understand if you are describing of how you think it works, or how youdl'd loke it to work.

Read the scenario I described. We do not track who created/last modified the file, so we only know that 10 other devices have a conflicting version. What name do you put in the conflict name? Pick one at random out of the 10? Also if we'd embed something as part of the name, ot would probably be first 5 characters of the device ID so it has meaning across all the devices, which I am not convinced is immensly useful.

It could be used by a application such as synctrayzor to know where it's originated
from?

On Thu, Aug 18, 2016, 14:42 Audrius Butkevicius notifications@github.com
wrote:

> It's hard to understand if you are describing of how you think it works,
> or how youdl'd loke it to work.
> 
> Read the scenario I described. We do not track who created/last modified
> the file, so we only know that 10 other devices have a conflicting version.
> Also if we'd embed something as part of the name, ot would probably be
> first 5 characters of the device ID, which I am not convinced is immensly
> useful.
>

> or mute the thread

> .
I'd suggest finding the original PR. There was an awful lot of discussion in there.
Yes, if the device(s) which created the conflict were named in the conflict file name, SyncTrayzor would display it. Doesn't make implementing it any more possible :P
I found PR #2559 and #2577, maybe this helps
Actually, I'm talking rubbish, we probably have what we need in the vector
Yes, but I wonder if the simplest approach á la Dropbox `Foo (abc123's conflicted copy).txt` would do, where `abc123` is the device where the conflict was detected/handled, i.e. the local device.
I am not sure I understand? You are saying that each would mark the others file as conflicted, essentially nodes having resolution logic that is dependant on the node it runs on?

Nah, I'm just saying that we could, instead of going with `foo.sync-conflict-$date.txt` go with `foo.sync-conflict-$date-$myShortID.txt` and that should be good enough for most cases. Or maybe my device name in some escaped format instead of short ID, but similar.

That is, I don't care who _caused_ the conflict, but who _resolved_ it, which is always "me" when I'm in the puller doing the rename.
I bet people won't like it, because if someone is misbehaving, it's hard to identify who.

I guess the other option is the set of devices involved in causing it, which is "me" and one or more other devices. As you say we should be able to tell that from the version vector and I guess could then go with `foo.sync-conflict-$date-$myShortID-$otherShortID-$thirdShortID-...-.txt`...
We only have two conflicts at a time, and versions could not be the same for two ids so where does the third id come from?

I was thinking every device that have changed it since. Consider that we are `A` and there are two other devices `B` and `C`. We have

`{A: 10, B: 20, C: 30}`

and now we suddenly find out about and want to sync

`{A: 8, B: 50, C: 50}`

It's based on something older than our version, so it's a conflict, but it's been updated by both B and C. Maybe we were offline for a while and made two changes to the file, while they pingponged a bunch of changes between them in the meantime.

But I thought it's never B: 50, C: 50, as next different version is always max(across all devices)+1, so in the case of:

`{A: 10, B: 20, C: 30}`, when B syncs the file from C, B's version is still 20, yet when B modifies the file it becomes 31?

B: 50, C: 50 would imply that both devices have different versions of the file, hence a conflict, so I am not sure if it's even possible to see a vector like that given it's merged, conflict resolved before it goes out?

Sure. But you might have the three devices connected and in sync:

A: `{A: 8, B: 20, C: 30}`
B: `{A: 8, B: 20, C: 30}`
C: `{A: 8, B: 20, C: 30}`

Now A disconnects from the world. Two local changes happen.

A: `{A: 10, B: 20, C: 30}`

B makes a change, C makes a change, B makes a change and so on, and they are connected

B: `{A: 8, B: 21, C: 30}`
...
C: `{A: 8, B: 21, C: 31}`
...
B & C: `{A: 8, B: 50, C: 50}`

Now we connect to A again.

A: `{A: 10, B: 20, C: 30}`
B: `{A: 8, B: 50, C: 50}`
C: `{A: 8, B: 50, C: 50}`

A is in conflict against both B and C.

of B makes a change again, it would have thought it becomes 32. If both b and c are at 50, whoever receives the update and does the &, should resolve the conflict and send out B50, C51 or B51, C50, no?

No. Maybe my example is unclear. There is no conflict between B & C, that's just two devices updating a file repeatedly. I picked 50 because it was a nice round number, but the procession

`{A: 8, B: 20, C: 30}` -> `{A: 8, B: 21, C: 30}` (updated by B) -> `{A: 8, B: 21, C: 31}` (synced to C, updated by C)

and

`{A: 8, B: 20, C: 30}` -> `{A: 9, B: 20, C: 30}` (updated by A, in isolation)

is enough for it to be in a state where A is in conflict with the version that both B and C have, and from A:s point of view the cause of the conflict is edits made by _both_ B and C. It can't know which of those edits were first, and it doesn't matter at the point it gets to do the conflict resolution.

Sorry, I'm late to this... Those were my PR's from a while back.  Also my memory is a bit fuzzy on all this but here goes:

IIRC, I also originally wanted to put the shortID in the filename but was having a problem carrying it from one class to the other (think it was from model class to fileversion or versionvector or something like that)

What I DID end up doing however was putting in code that would (if -audit flag was enabled) cause each client to write down if an add/change/delete to a file was because of it's own local scan of the hard drive OR if it came from another device.  My thoughts then were that we could eventually take all these messages (that are currently written to the audit log of each client) and correlate them into a central synced db so we could know who made the original change of a file.  That part never got added but it should be easier to do with the base code in there.

The commit I'm describing is this I think: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/commit/86ca58e2a96c01d1d67435602443c35b050ee322

So basically... Look for the LocalDiskUpdated event in the audit.log when you change a file (make sure to restart with -audit flag).  The behavior SHOULD be that only the client(s) that change the file on their own hard drive between scans, fire that event, and the ones that receive the file from network do not add that event to their audit log.  Therefor the client with the audit log that has this event is the guilty one.

This should be enough info for someone to write code to announce who the last client to make the change was.  Maybe even add it to version vector and/or GUI... or something?

--- EDIT ---
Looks like the line in the audit log has "LocalChangeDetected" in it, from my tests.

AudriusButkevicius wrote (in response to where file came from):

> I actually think it''s impossible in some cases, as we don't track where the file originated from

That's correct from what I found in my pouring through this problem a few months ago.  But as I stated above I wrote some code to write in the local audit log whether an add/change/delete of a file was done on the local drive or from someone else on the network (see my above post).  This logic could easily be used to determine who the ultimate modifier was.

But of course that assumes most/all clients are online and relatively fast "convergence", OR that many others don't modify this file while everyone else is offline.  Otherwise the complexity of "who made the change" becomes bigger fast.  :)

I'm thinking that the device that generates the conflict file can just include the name when the file is created, easier to know which version is which then. We don't need everyone elses names to do this.
